The date when the robbery occurred, which is central to understanding the timeline of the crime and the ongoing investigation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The exact time window during which the robbery occurred, indicating how quickly the thieves carried out the heist—only four minutes to break in and leave.

keyTakeAways: The stolen jewelry is estimated to be worth $102 million (88 million euros), making it one of the most valuable art heists in history.
The heist took place in the Apollo Gallery at the Louvre Museum in Paris, where thieves used a truck-mounted ladder to break a window and enter through a vulnerable point.
The stolen items include a royal diadem with 24 Ceylon sapphires and 1,083 diamonds, and a Napoleon-era emerald necklace and earrings set, both of significant historical and royal value.
Eight of the nine stolen items remain unaccounted for, raising serious concerns about the possibility of permanent loss.
The French government and public have expressed deep concern over the security failures exposed by the heist, including unsecured windows and public placement of a basket lift.
Investigators have recovered a scooter, a helmet, and are analyzing a truck for DNA and fingerprints, but lack solid leads on the perpetrators.
Experts, including French lawmakers and art recovery professionals, believe the jewelry may have been dismantled and sold on the black market or melted down for financial gain.
The heist is suspected to be linked to organized crime, with the motivation being money laundering rather than theft for cultural or personal gain.
This incident echoes the 1911 Mona Lisa theft and the 1998 Camille Corot heist, highlighting a long-standing vulnerability in high-profile museum security.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A high-profile heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, estimated to have stolen jewelry worth $102 million, occurred in October 2025 when two armed men used a truck-mounted ladder to break into the Apollo Gallery, entering through an unsecured window and stealing royal artifacts including a royal diadem and a Napoleon-era emerald necklace. The entire operation took only seven minutes, with the perpetrators leaving on scooters along the Seine. Despite a large investigative effort involving around 100 officers and the recovery of a scooter and helmet, no solid leads have been identified. Experts believe the stolen items may have already been dismantled and sold on the black market, possibly by organized criminals seeking to launder money. The incident has exposed significant security flaws in the museum, prompting national condemnation and political accountability. Historically, similar heists—including the 1911 Mona Lisa theft and the 1998 Corot heist—underscore the enduring vulnerability of cultural treasures to theft.
title: Stolen Louvre Jewelry Estimated to Be Worth $102 Million, Prosecutor Says, as Search Continues
